content: quote: http://www.adn.com/news/alaska/story/713823.html Looks like the utlities involved are already government owned... so this would be merging 6 public utilities into one more efficient department. Saves money and reduces overhead... lower taxes and better public investment in future energy development... The individual entities seem to be on board and supportive of the idea as well. Thanks for bringing this up though. I was wondering how ol' Sarah was doing up in Alaska. As busy as ever I see saving the people of Alaska money and planning for the future! "Common sense isn't."
quote: http://www.adn.com/news/alaska/story/713823.html

content: Lessee, Golden....., Mantanuska...., not listed on the exchanges, the other two include MUNICIPLE and CITY.....ASSOCIATION...and these are private companies? According to thge story, the facilities of many are within 15 years of the end of their generation capabilities. Seems to me that seeking alternatives now is good thinking, and, considering the time lapsese in getting the permits to replace generating facilities, 15 years is none too early. aFTER ALL THE MALTHUSIANS playacting as "envioenmentalists", would be pleased to let the Alaskans freeze and starve in the dark as the power plants wore out.

title: Republican Gov. Sarah Palin Pushs To Socialize Alaska Utility Companies

content: quote: Well, I made a point blank statement - "The cheapest and most efficient power in the country is all created by Publicly owned Power." The above is just fact. Could you elucidate on your objections? Care to challenge my statement? Dave Maybe I did not understand your comment as much as I thought I did. Need some refinement I guess on my part. "http://www.world-nuclear.org/sym/2002/pdf/may.pdf" I took it that you meant that a private run corp was not as efficient as producing energy as publically owned power companies. The cost to produce vs output volume been repeatedly proven to be more efficient when privately owned. Not ALWAYS but the majority of the time. I will agree that de-regulation half arsed will drive up costs to the consumer short term and if not completely deregulated then long term as well. So that is what I thought you meant by cheaper and more efficient. When it comes to distribution, the privately owned companies running power transmission lines are more efficient when fabrication or maintenance is concerned. When it comes to the size of need, generally the largest areas in megawatt consumption are better served by the private companies than the public when comparing costs per kilowatt due to the efficiency. If you meant what I pay per month de-regulation vs regulated I agree… It is cheaper when regulated although it has been argued (aside from allowing super conglomerates of power companies to be formed like AT &T of old) that complete de-regulation nation wide would allow Florida cities to pick and choose buying power from New Mexico or Vermont instead of much closer to home. (Not talking peak power) This message has been edited. Last edited by: ACR26, Thu 12 March 2009 07:51 AM
quote: Well, I made a point blank statement - "The cheapest and most efficient power in the country is all created by Publicly owned Power." The above is just fact. Could you elucidate on your objections? Care to challenge my statement? Dave

When it comes to the size of need, generally the largest areas in megawatt consumption are better served by the private companies than the public when comparing costs per kilowatt due to the efficiency. If you meant what I pay per month de-regulation vs regulated I agree… It is cheaper when regulated although it has been argued (aside from allowing super conglomerates of power companies to be formed like AT &T of old) that complete de-regulation nation wide would allow Florida cities to pick and choose buying power from New Mexico or Vermont instead of much closer to home. (Not talking peak power) This message has been edited. Last edited by: ACR26, Thu 12 March 2009 07:51 AM
title: Republican Gov. Sarah Palin Pushs To Socialize Alaska Utility Companies

content: And in Virginia (Crackerjacks home State) they subscribe to the same ideals of Sarah Palin, Gov of Alaska. A three member commission elected by the General Assembly governs a well run department to bring the best service and prices to their customers in Virgina. Our City (Jacksonville)takes care of the Water, Electric, Sewage, refuse and Port Authority. I know very few folks that have their own wells, Solar/Generator power and ceasepool. City living you darn sure will do business with the Town Hall either buying or selling power.
reply: And in Virginia (Crackerjacks home State) they subscribe to the same ideals of Sarah Palin, Gov of Alaska. content: quote: Originally posted by ACR26: quote: Well, I made a point blank statement - "The cheapest and most efficient power in the country is all created by Publicly owned Power." The above is just fact. Could you elucidate on your objections? Care to challenge my statement? Dave Maybe I did not understand your comment as much as I thought I did. Need some refinement I guess on my part. "http://www.world-nuclear.org/sym/2002/pdf/may.pdf" I took it that you meant that a private run corp was not as efficient as producing energy as publically owned power companies. The cost to produce vs output volume been repeatedly proven to be more efficient when privately owned. Not ALWAYS but the majority of the time. I will agree that de-regulation half arsed will drive up costs to the consumer short term and if not completely deregulated then long term as well. So that is what I thought you meant by cheaper and more efficient. When it comes to distribution, the privately owned companies running power transmission lines are more efficient when fabrication or maintenance is concerned. When it comes to the size of need, generally the largest areas in megawatt consumption are better served by the private companies than the public when comparing costs per kilowatt due to the efficiency. If you meant what I pay per month de-regulation vs regulated I agree… It is cheaper when regulated although it has been argued (aside from allowing super conglomerates of power companies to be formed like AT &T of old) that complete de-regulation nation wide would allow Florida cities to pick and choose buying power from New Mexico or Vermont instead of much closer to home. (Not talking peak power) The PDF you link to, includes such corrupt and backwards owners as the former Soviet Union, who couldn't even keep one of their plants from turning into a mass of slag. The ten cheapest sources of power in the United States are publicly owned. SOme of them run Nuclear power plants. But nuclear power only accounts for 12 percent of electricity. Now, if you want to compare a corrupt pulicly owned power plant with an honest privately owned plant - If those were your criterium, you could make your point. But here in the US corruption seems to be a monopoly of private interests - So while California endured rolling blackouts because of Enron, San Francisco enjoyed cheap and regular electricity from it's publicly owned power plants. Since you admit that deregulation poorly handled doesn't work out to well, I wont rub in the fact that here in New York, our rates have skyrocketed since deregulation, and recent reports have demonstrated that this is due to corruption. Dave

So that is what I thought you meant by cheaper and more efficient. When it comes to distribution, the privately owned companies running power transmission lines are more efficient when fabrication or maintenance is concerned. When it comes to the size of need, generally the largest areas in megawatt consumption are better served by the private companies than the public when comparing costs per kilowatt due to the efficiency. If you meant what I pay per month de-regulation vs regulated I agree… It is cheaper when regulated although it has been argued (aside from allowing super conglomerates of power companies to be formed like AT &T of old) that complete de-regulation nation wide would allow Florida cities to pick and choose buying power from New Mexico or Vermont instead of much closer to home. (Not talking peak power) This message has been edited. Last edited by: ACR26, Thu 12 March 2009 07:51 AM
quote: Well, I made a point blank statement - "The cheapest and most efficient power in the country is all created by Publicly owned Power." The above is just fact. Could you elucidate on your objections? Care to challenge my statement? Dave
reply: Maybe I did not understand your comment as much as I thought I did. Need some refinement I guess on my part. "http://www.world-nuclear.org/sym/2002/pdf/may.pdf" I took it that you meant that a private run corp was not as efficient as producing energy as publically owned power companies. The cost to produce vs output volume been repeatedly proven to be more efficient when privately owned. Not ALWAYS but the majority of the time. I will agree that de-regulation half arsed will drive up costs to the consumer short term and if not completely deregulated then long term as well. So that is what I thought you meant by cheaper and more efficient. When it comes to distribution, the privately owned companies running power transmission lines are more efficient when fabrication or maintenance is concerned. When it comes to the size of need, generally the largest areas in megawatt consumption are better served by the private companies than the public when comparing costs per kilowatt due to the efficiency. If you meant what I pay per month de-regulation vs regulated I agree… It is cheaper when regulated although it has been argued (aside from allowing super conglomerates of power companies to be formed like AT &T of old) that complete de-regulation nation wide would allow Florida cities to pick and choose buying power from New Mexico or Vermont instead of much closer to home. (Not talking peak power) This message has been edited. Last edited by: ACR26, Thu 12 March 2009 07:51 AM
title: Republican Gov. Sarah Palin Pushs To Socialize Alaska Utility Companies

content: And in Virginia (Crackerjacks home State) they subscribe to the same ideals of Sarah Palin, Gov of Alaska. A three member commission elected by the General Assembly governs a well run department to bring the best service and prices to their customers in Virgina. Our City (Jacksonville)takes care of the Water, Electric, Sewage, refuse and Port Authority. I know very few folks that have their own wells, Solar/Generator power and ceasepool. City living you darn sure will do business with the Town Hall either buying or selling power.

content: Again... Mr. Crackerjack is wrong. "Municipal Associations" are public... not private organizations. Just because they're town or city government instead of state doesn't mean they're not gov't. Silly ;-) (And merging them likely will CUT costs and labor to run them more efficiently.... hard to argue that's big gov't) "Common sense isn't."

content: quote: Originally posted by ACR26: quote: Well, I made a point blank statement - "The cheapest and most efficient power in the country is all created by Publicly owned Power." The above is just fact. Could you elucidate on your objections? Care to challenge my statement? Dave Maybe I did not understand your comment as much as I thought I did. Need some refinement I guess on my part. "http://www.world-nuclear.org/sym/2002/pdf/may.pdf" I took it that you meant that a private run corp was not as efficient as producing energy as publically owned power companies. The cost to produce vs output volume been repeatedly proven to be more efficient when privately owned. Not ALWAYS but the majority of the time. I will agree that de-regulation half arsed will drive up costs to the consumer short term and if not completely deregulated then long term as well. So that is what I thought you meant by cheaper and more efficient. When it comes to distribution, the privately owned companies running power transmission lines are more efficient when fabrication or maintenance is concerned. When it comes to the size of need, generally the largest areas in megawatt consumption are better served by the private companies than the public when comparing costs per kilowatt due to the efficiency. If you meant what I pay per month de-regulation vs regulated I agree… It is cheaper when regulated although it has been argued (aside from allowing super conglomerates of power companies to be formed like AT &T of old) that complete de-regulation nation wide would allow Florida cities to pick and choose buying power from New Mexico or Vermont instead of much closer to home. (Not talking peak power) The PDF you link to, includes such corrupt and backwards owners as the former Soviet Union, who couldn't even keep one of their plants from turning into a mass of slag. The ten cheapest sources of power in the United States are publicly owned. SOme of them run Nuclear power plants. But nuclear power only accounts for 12 percent of electricity. Now, if you want to compare a corrupt pulicly owned power plant with an honest privately owned plant - If those were your criterium, you could make your point. But here in the US corruption seems to be a monopoly of private interests - So while California endured rolling blackouts because of Enron, San Francisco enjoyed cheap and regular electricity from it's publicly owned power plants. Since you admit that deregulation poorly handled doesn't work out to well, I wont rub in the fact that here in New York, our rates have skyrocketed since deregulation, and recent reports have demonstrated that this is due to corruption. Dave
